brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine if digital photography on a Smartphone and the
      Remote Food Photography Method (RFPM) can estimate infant formula intake. This is a
      validation study; there is no hypothesis.

clinical_study.brief_title: Remote Food Photography Method in Infants

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  ≥ 18 years of age

          -  Willing to complete 2 study visits at Pennington Biomedical (PBRC)

study_pop.textblock:
Up to 75 men and women will be recruited to participate in a 2-week pilot study involving
        infant formula preparation. Participation is open to all adult individuals.

link.description: PBRC Website description and webscreening link

clinical_study.official_title: Baby Bottle: Remote Food Photography Method in Infants

other_outcome.description: A caregiver will be defined as an individual who is a parent, grandparent, sibling, aunt or uncle, or nanny or babysitter who has provided care to an infant within the last 12 months.
other_outcome.measure: Variability between caregivers and non-caregivers in kilocalories of prepared infant formula
other_outcome.time_frame: Measures will be performed twice about 5-10 days apart

primary_outcome.measure: Grams of prepared infant formula detected in a bottle using the Remote Food Photography Method as a validation measure against grams of prepared formula measured via direct weighing
primary_outcome.time_frame: Measures will be performed twice about 5-10 days apart

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Inter- and intra- individual preparation variability of kilocalories of prepared infant formula detected
secondary_outcome.measure: Ability of Remote Food Photography Method to measure kilocalories of prepared infant formula
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Measures will be performed twice about 5-10 days apart
